description: Behavioral variant of frontotemporal dementia (bv-FTD) is a form of frontotemporal dementia (FTD; see this term), characterized by progressive behavioral impairment and a decline in executive function with frontal lobe-predominant atrophy.
name: Behavioral variant of frontotemporal dementia

description: Quantification of the activity of the enzyme renin in the blood. Renin activates the renin-angiotensin system by cleaving angiotensinogen, produced by the liver, to yield angiotensin I, which is further converted into angiotensin II by ACE, the angiotensin-converting enzyme primarily within the capillaries of the lungs.
name: plasma renin activity measurement

description: Quantification of the error rate reflecting the proportion of trials in an antisaccade task that resulted in a prosaccade response. An antisaccade task invovles the suppression of the involuntary saccade towards a stimulus (prosaccade response) following a period of fixation on a motionless target.
name: antisaccade response measurement

description: Infections with species in the genus pneumocystis, a fungus causing interstitial plasma cell pneumonia (pneumonia, pneumocystis) and other infections in humans and other mammals. Immunocompromised patients, especially those with aids, are particularly susceptible to these infections. Extrapulmonary sites are rare but seen occasionally.

name: interleukin 18 receptor 1 measurement

description: Quantification of the volume of the frontal pole.

description: Quantification of carnitine levels in a sample.

description: Cystic renal cell carcinoma includes any malignant neoplasm of renal tubular epithelium which presents as a fluid-filled mass. Approximately 15 per cent of cases of renal cell carcinoma will be cystic on radiologic and pathologic examination. The clinical features of cystic renal cell carcinoma are similar to those which are solid. The radiographic and pathologic findings of cystic renal cell carcinoma are often more confusing and less specific than the findings of renal cell carcinoma which are predominantly solid. There are four basic pathologic mechanisms resulting in cystic renal cell carcinoma: intrinsic multiloculated growth; intrinsic unilocular growth (cystadenocarcinoma); cystic necrosis; and origin from the epithelial lining of a preexisting simple cyst. There are three basic radiologic patterns of cystic renal cell carcinoma: unilocular cystic mass, multiloculated cystic mass, and discrete mural nodule in a cystic mass. Cystic renal cell carcinoma is often extremely difficult to differentiate from non-neoplastic, benign neoplastic, and other malignant neoplastic masses utilizing radiologic studies alone. This review presents the clinical, pathologic, and radiographic features of cystic renal cell carcinoma and discusses its radiologic differential diagnosis.
name: cystic renal cell carcinoma

description: Tularemia is an infection caused by the bacterium Francisella tularensis. Humans can become infected in several different ways: by handling infected animals, through tick or deer fly bites, by drinking contaminated water, or by inhaling contaminated dust or aerosols. Person-to-person transmission has not been reported. The type of tularemia and the particular signs and symptoms vary depending on how the bacteria enter the body. However, fever is seen in most cases. Though tularemia can be life-threatening, most infections can be treated with antibiotics.

description: Breast cancer occuring in women with a family history indicative or being a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation carrier, but genetic screening for these genes has failed to find clinically significant mutations.
name: BRCAX breast cancer

hasExactSynonym: BRCA1/2 negative high risk breast cancer
BRCA1/BRCA2 negative high risk breast cancer

description: A pathologic process in the larynx that affects the production of speech. Causes include vocal cord paresis, vocal cord nodule, vocal cord polyp, and laryngitis. [database_cross_reference: NCIt:C3441]
name: voice disorders

description: Oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis affecting a total of more than 4 joints after the first 6 months of disease.
name: extended oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis

description: Any process that results in a change in state or activity of a cell or an organism (in terms of movement, secretion, enzyme production, gene expression, etc.) as a result of a bisphosphonate stimulus. Bisphosphonates are a class of drug which inhibit bone resorption, used to prevent the loss of bone density in osteoporosis and similar diseases.
name: response to bisphosphonate

description: Quantification of the amount of leukemia inhibitory factor receptor in a sample
name: leukemia inhibitory factor receptor measurement

description: The result of a measurement of circulating BK polyomavirus-specific antibodies.
name: BK polyomavirus seropositivity

description: Quantification of 4-deoxythreonic acid in a sample.
name: 4-deoxythreonic acid measurement

description: The determination of the amount of 40s ribosomal protein S7 in a sample
name: 40s ribosomal protein S7 measurement

description: The determination of the amount of apolipoprotein E (isoform E3) in a sample
name: apolipoprotein E (isoform E3) measurement

description: The determination of the amount of DNA topoisomerase 1 in a sample
name: DNA topoisomerase 1 measurement

description: The determination of the amount of focal adhesion kinase 1 in a sample
name: focal adhesion kinase 1 measurement

description: The determination of the amount of granzyme h in a sample
name: granzyme h measurement

description: The determination of the amount of tata-box-binding protein in a sample
name: tata-box-binding protein measurement

description: Thermal burns fall into six categories, including scalds, thermal contact burns, electrical burns, chemical burns, radiation burns, and burns caused by fire.
name: thermal burn

description: ABO phenotype B, corresponding to the genotype BO or BB.
name: blood group B

description: A poorly differentiated non-small cell lung carcinoma composed of large polygonal cells without evidence of glandular or squamous differentiation
name: anaplastic lung carcinoma

description: A malignant epithelial neoplasm characterized by the presence of neoplastic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, small amount of cytoplasm, and peripheral nuclear palisading.
name: Basaloid Carcinoma

description: A hamartoma that is characterized by the presence of chondroid elements.
name: Chondroid Hamartoma

description: A WHO grade I meningioma characterized by the coexistence of meningothelial cells and fibrous architectural patterns.
name: Transitional Meningioma

description: Abnormal responses to sunlight or artificial light due to extreme reactivity of light-absorbing molecules in tissues. It refers almost exclusively to skin photosensitivity, including sunburn, reactions due to repeated prolonged exposure in the absence of photosensitizing factors, and reactions requiring photosensitizing factors such as photosensitizing agents and certain diseases. With restricted reference to skin tissue, it does not include photosensitivity of the eye to light, as in photophobia or photosensitive epilepsy.
name: photosensitivity disease

description: A hematology test result that indicates the presence of an increased white blood cell count and increased neutrophil precursors resembling leukemia, in a peripheral blood smear.
name: leukemoid reaction

description: A condition characterized by a combination of ostium secundum atrial septal defect and an acquired mitral valve stenosis.
name: Lutembacher's syndrome

description: A acute monocytic leukemia that occurs in an adult.
name: adult acute monocytic leukemia

hasExactSynonym: M5b adult acute differentiated monocytic leukemia

description: A rare endometrial carcinoma characterized by the presence of both malignant glandular and malignant squamous cellular components.
name: endometrial adenosquamous carcinoma

description: Spinocerebellar ataxia type 28 (SCA28) is a very rare subtype of type I autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxia (ADCA type I; see this term). It is characterized by juvenile onset, slowly progressive cerebellar ataxia due to Purkinje cell degeneration.
name: Spinocerebellar ataxia type 28
Male infertility due to large-headed multiflagellar polyploid spermatozoa
Metabolic myopathy due to lactate transporter defect

description: Osteogenesis imperfecta type I is a mild type of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI; see this term), a genetic disorder characterized by increased bone fragility, low bone mass and susceptibility to bone fractures.
name: Osteogenesis imperfecta type 1
Hypogonadism - mitral valve prolapse - intellectual disability

description: A non-seminomatous malignant germ cell tumor composed of primitive germ cells. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor in the pediatric population. It occurs in the infant testis, ovary, sacrococcygeal region, vagina, uterus, prostate, abdomen, liver, retroperitoneum, thorax, and pineal/third ventricle. The tumor mimics the yolk sac of the embryo and produces alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). Treatment includes: surgical resection, radiation, and chemotherapy. This tumor is very responsive to chemotherapy regimens that include cisplatinum.
name: endodermal sinus tumor

description: A renal infectious disease and is_a Human immunodeficiency virus infectious disease that results_in infection located_in kidney, has_material_basis_in has_material_basis_in Human immunodeficiency virus 1 or has_material_basis_in Human immunodeficiency virus 2. The infection has_symptom nephrotic-range proteinuria (>3.5 g/d), has_symptom azotemia, has_symptom hypoalbuminemia, and has_symptom hyperlipidemia.
name: HIV-associated nephropathy

description: Narrowing of the left atrioventricular mitral orifice.
name: mitral valve stenosis

description: quantification of the change in HDL cholesterol levels in an individual over time, eg over the course of several hours after a high-fat meal or following treatment with a cholesterol-lowering drug
name: HDL cholesterol change measurement

description: quantification of some aspect of an individual's micrbiome of the gut
name: gut microbiome measurement

description: quantification of the amount of interleukin 1 receptor-like 1 in a sample
name: interleukin 1 receptor-like 1 measurement

description: quantification of the interaction between some phenotype and biological sex
name: sex interaction measurement

description: A necrotizing vasculitis that affects medium-sized arteries, it is usually idiopathic, and may be triggered by viral infections (Hepatitis B, also others). A multisystem disease, it most commonly affects skin (nodules, livedo reticularis) and peripheral nerves; higher morbidity is associated with gastrointestinal, central nervous system, cardiac, and/or other organ involvement. Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are typically negative. [ NCI ]
name: Polyarteritis Nodosa

description: A combined mitochondrial respiratory chain deficiency associated with epileptic encephalopathy and a complex movement disorder.
name: Combined oxidative phosphorylation defect type 27

description: The determination of the ratio of immature reticulocytes to total reticulocytes present in a sample. [ NCI ]
name: Immature Reticulocyte Fraction Measurement

description: NDHMSD is a severe neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by profound developmental delay, severe intellectual disability with absent speech, muscular hypotonia, and a hyperkinetic movement disorder. Additional features may include cortical blindness, generalized cerebral atrophy, and seizures (summary by Lemke et al., 2016).
name: neurodevelopmental disorder with or without hyperkinetic movements and seizures, autosomal dominant

hasExactSynonym: neurodevelopmental disorder with or without hyperkinetic movements and seizures, autosomal recessive

description: Itching in the vagina from abnormal discharge.
name: abnormal vaginal discharge itching

description: Epilepsy, hearing loss, and intellectual disability syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by severe neurologic impairment including intellectual disability, intractable epilepsy, microcephaly, abnormal muscle tone, and sensorineural hearing loss. Most affected individuals are nonambulatory, cannot sit unassisted, and have no speech development. More variable features include feeding difficulties, poor growth, cortical visual impairment, spasticity, scoliosis, immunodeficiency, and thrombocytopenia.
name: epilepsy, hearing loss, and intellectual disability syndrome

description: A sign or symptom concerning the intake of food and/or fluids.
name: sign or symptom concerning food and fluid intake

description: Dryness of the mouth resulting from reduced salivary secretion.
name: xerostomia

description: Quantification of the amount of Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor D in the sample.
name: vascular endothelial growth factor D measurement

description: The determination of the amount of bone morphogenetic protein 7 in a sample
name: bone morphogenetic protein 7 measurement

description: The determination of the amount of DNA repair protein rad51 homolog 1 in a sample
name: DNA repair protein rad51 homolog 1 measurement

description: The determination of the amount of ephrin-A4 in a sample
name: ephrin-A4 measurement

description: The determination of the amount of protein rev_hv2be in a sample
name: protein rev_hv2be measurement

description: The determination of the amount of receptor tyrosine-protein kinase erbb-3 in a sample
name: receptor tyrosine-protein kinase erbb-3 measurement

description: The determination of the amount of sonic hedgehog protein in a sample
name: sonic hedgehog protein measurement

description: The determination of the amount of thrombospondin-4 in a sample
name: thrombospondin-4 measurement

description: A measure of the thickness of one or more layers of the retina. It is measured with various imaging tools including ultrasound, optical coherence tomography (OCT), confocal microscopy, and biometry. Reduced retinal layer thickness is one of the biomarkers used for the diagnosis of glaucoma.
name: retinal layer thickness measurement

description: A WHO grade II, slow growing tumor of children and young adults, usually located intraventricularly. It is the most common ependymal neoplasm. It often causes clinical symptoms by blocking cerebrospinal fluid pathways. Key histological features include perivascular pseudorosettes and ependymal rosettes. (WHO)
name: ependymoma

description: Multiple symmetric lipomatosis (MSL) is a rare subcutaneous tissue disease characterized by growth of symmetric non-encapsulated masses of adipose tissue mostly around the face and neck with variable clinical repercussions (e.g. reduced neck mobility, compression of respiratory structures).
name: multiple symmetric lipomatosis

description: Blood-filled UTERUS.
name: hemometra

description: A twisting in the intestine (INTESTINES) that can cause INTESTINAL OBSTRUCTION.
name: intestinal volvulus

hasExactSynonym: Twist of intestine, bowel, or colon

description: A term used pathologically to describe BILIRUBIN staining of the BASAL GANGLIA; BRAIN STEM; and CEREBELLUM and clinically to describe a syndrome associated with HYPERBILIRUBINEMIA. Clinical features include athetosis, MUSCLE SPASTICITY or hypotonia, impaired vertical gaze, and DEAFNESS. Nonconjugated bilirubin enters the brain and acts as a neurotoxin, often in association with conditions that impair the BLOOD-BRAIN BARRIER (e.g., SEPSIS). This condition occurs primarily in neonates (INFANT, NEWBORN), but may rarely occur in adults. (Menkes, Textbook of Child Neurology, 5th ed, p613)
name: kernicterus

description: Self-limited inflammation of the thyroid gland characterized by the presence of multinucleated giant cells. Patients present with neck pain, often associated with fever and dysphagia. The clinical course includes an initial phase of hyperthyroidism, followed by a phase of hypothyroidism, and eventually a return to normal thyroid function.
name: subacute thyroiditis
Benign infantile focal epilepsy with midline spikes and wave during sleep
Qualitative or quantitative defects of myotilin
Partial deletion of the long arm of chromosome X

hasExactSynonym: Partial monosomy of the short arm of chromosome X

description: Heritable pulmonary arterial hypertension (HPAH) is a form of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH, see this term) characterized by elevated pulmonary arterial resistance leading to right heart failure, occurring in in a familial context. HPAH is progressive and potentially fatal.
name: Heritable pulmonary arterial hypertension
